title: Step 3 – Apply for a UPPMAX Account
text:
Once your project has been approved in SUPR, your allocation on Gorilla, Pelle, and/or Lutra becomes active.
To log in to these systems, you must also have a UPPMAX user account. This account is separate from SUPR and is required for accessing the compute clusters operated by UPPMAX.


The UPPMAX systems (Gorilla, Pelle, Lutra) are operated by Uppsala University.
SUPR is used to manage the resources applications and allocations, but you still need a local UPPMAX user account so you can:

log in via SSH

access project directories

run jobs on the clusters

use software modules and storage areas





Log into SUPR here: https://supr.naiss.se, using the same identity you used for SUPR.

In the left hand menu, click Accounts.

Under the heading Account Requests, click Request account.

[MORE INFO NEEDED]




UPPMAX staff will approve your request and create your user account.

Once created, you will receive an email with login details (including your username).

After activation, you can log in to Gorilla, Pelle, or Lutra immediately.




When your UPPMAX account is active, you can:

connect to the clusters via SSH

access your project directory

start running jobs and workflows

use software modules and storage areas

monitor resource usage

Click below for a shoer summary of how to log on and work on the servers.
Step 4: Access after Approval

For questions or problems with your UPPMAX account, contact:
support@slu.se

title: Step 2 – Apply for Resources via SLU Local 2025
text: Once you have a SUPR account, you can apply for compute and storage resources through the SLU Local 2026 round.

title: Step 2 – Apply for Resources via SLU Local 2025
text:
Before You Apply
Prepare the following information:

Project title and short description

Estimated compute needs (cores, memory, runtime)

Estimated storage needs (GB or TB, and expected duration)

Internal project number or cost centre for billing ([MORE INFO NEEDED: required SLU financial details])

title: Step 2 – Apply for Resources via SLU Local 2025
section: Find the “SLU Local 2026” Call in SUPR
text:
Find the “SLU Local 2026” Call in SUPR
[MORE INFO NEEDED]

Log in to SUPR: https://supr.naiss.se

Go to the section for Rounds on the menu on the left side.

Below the panels for the different default rounds, click: “You can also view all rounds (including closed and decided).”” 
Under “Local Rounds” select “SLU Local 2026”
Click “Create new proposal” to start a new application.

title: Step 2 – Apply for Resources via SLU Local 2025
text:
Fill in the Application
Typical sections include:

Project Information

Project title

Scientific area (e.g. bioinformatics, genomics, ecology)

Short abstract in clear, non-technical language

Extended description of methods and type of analyses



Resources Requested
Describe what you need on:

Gorilla

Pelle

Lutra

For each system, specify:

type of workload (e.g. RNA-seq, WGS, metagenomics, modelling)

number of cores / nodes needed

expected walltime per job

total compute hours required over the project period

storage needs (active project storage and any longer-term storage)

[MORE INFO NEEDED: specific unit used for compute accounting – core hours, CPU hours, GPU hours, etc.]


Project Members
Add:

PI and co-applicants

other users who should have access to the allocation

All listed users normally need a SUPR account.


Budget and Billing
Provide:

SLU project number and/or cost centre

responsible person for the budget

[MORE INFO NEEDED: exact format of project numbers and any required reference text for invoices]

title: Step 2 – Apply for Resources via SLU Local 2025
text:
Submission and Review

Check that all mandatory fields are completed.

Submit the application in SUPR.

You will receive a confirmation email from SUPR.

The application is reviewed according to SLU and NAISS procedures.

You are notified by email when the allocation has been approved.

[MORE INFO NEEDED: expected review time and decision schedule]

title: Step 2 – Apply for Resources via SLU Local 2025
text:
After Approval
When your application is approved:

The project and allocation are created in SUPR, and activated from the requested starting date.

Users added to the project are granted access to the selected systems.

If you do not have an account at UPPMAX, you need to apply for one before you can access the servers:
Step 3: Apply for an UPPMAX account
If you already have an account at UPPMAX, you can immediately proceed to connect and start using the resources:

support@slu.se

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
UPPMAX (Uppsala Multidisciplinary Center for Advanced Computational Science) is the local NAISS centre at Uppsala University that operates the systems you can apply to in SLU Local Round.
To request compute and storage resources at UPPMAX, you must first have an active user account in the NAISS/SUPR system.

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
UPPMAX (Uppsala Multidisciplinary Center for Advanced Computational Science) is the local NAISS centre at Uppsala University that operates the systems you can apply to in SLU Local Round.
To request compute and storage resources at UPPMAX, you must first have an active user account in the NAISS/SUPR system.

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
What is NAISS/SUPR?
NAISS (National Academic Infrastructure for Supercomputing in Sweden) provides national high-performance computing and storage resources.
SUPR/NAISS is the web portal used to manage:

user accounts

project applications

resource allocations

You access SUPR here: https://supr.naiss.se

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
Who Can Apply?

Employees and researchers at SLU can apply to get resources via the SLU round.

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
Create a SUPR Account

Fill out & submit account request form.







Tip




If possible, use Register with Federated Identity.
If this option doesn’t work for you, use instead Register without Federated Identity.




Fill in your contact details and affiliation with Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet.

Confirm your email address if requested.







Tip



When registering or updating your profile:

Select Sveriges lantbruksuniversitet as your organisation.

Add your research group, department or unit in the profile description if relevant.

This makes it easier to link you to the correct projects and allocations.

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
Accept NAISS user agreement
Just after creating the SUPR account, on the page you are taken to, there will be a section titled “User Agreement” at the very top. Just under it is the button named “Accept NAISS User Agreement”.
Alternately, if you do this at a later point. Login to SUPR. At the very top it will say “NAISS User Agreement Pending”.






Tip




If possible, use the With SWAMID option - this is much faster!
Alternatively, use Alternative: Offline via Paper Form. Here you will have to print out, sign and send in the form. This may take up to a week.

title: Step 1 – Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
text:
After Your Account Is Created
Once your SUPR account is active, you can:

be added as a member to existing projects, and

submit new applications in calls such as “SLU Local 2026”.

Continue to see how to apply for compute and storage resources:
Step 2: Apply for Resources via "SLU Local 2026"

For questions or problems with registration, contact:
support@slu.se

title: Compute & Storage Resources for SLU
text:
This page provides an overview of how to apply for pay-as-you-use compute and storage resources at UPPMAX, what systems are available, how to manage your allocation, and where to get support.



Step 1: Apply for a NAISS/SUPR Account
Step 2: Apply for Resources via "SLU Local 2026"
Step 3: Apply for an Uppmax account
Step 4: Access After Approval




Through the SLU round, the following resources can be applied for at UPPMAX:

Pelle: compute resources. Can be applied for individually, or with additional storage on Gorilla.
Gorilla: active project storage. Can be applied for individually, or in an application together with a compute project on Pelle.
Lutra: long term storage. Needs to be applied for in a separate application from Pelle and/or Gorilla.




Allocations on Pelle and Gorilla can be requested for up to a year at a time. If needed, they can be renewed for up to another year at a time, for as long as you need the resources. You will receive an email reminder before your current allocation expires.
Once no longer needed, you can simply remove your data and not request a prolongation of your project when it is running out.
Storage allocations on Lutra will be granted for four years at a time.
Questions pending confirmation: - Is termination handled through SUPR? Yes, should be automatic. [MORE INFO NEEDED] - Is a one‑month notice period required? Again, that should be automatic - if no resources are used none are billed. [MORE INFO NEEDED] - Should users notify NAISS, SLU IT, or both? Sounded like they don’t have to notify anyone, just not use the allocations anymore. [MORE INFO NEEDED]

title: About
text:
This initiative is a joint collaboration between SLU, represented by the SLU Bioinformatics Infrastructure (SLUBI) and SLU IT, and UPPMAX at Uppsala University.
Together, these partners provide access to high-performance compute and storage resources, user support, and the technical expertise needed to enable efficient and secure data-intensive research at SLU.

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text: When your project has been approved in SUPR, your allocation on Gorilla, Pelle and/or Lutra becomes active.

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text:
When Is Access Activated?

Access is granted as soon as the allocation is approved and registered in SUPR.

You do not need to submit any additional forms.

You and your project members can log in using your existing credentials.

[MORE INFO NEEDED: typical delay between decision and technical activation, if any]

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text:
Login and Connection
You normally access the systems via SSH from a terminal.
Example (replace user and host with the correct ones):
ssh your-username@gorilla.XXX
ssh your-username@pelle.uppmax.uu.se
ssh your-username@lutra.XXX
[MORE INFO NEEDED: Exact directory paths and structure on Gorilla, Pelle, and Lutra], VPN?
If a VPN or SLU-specific network access is required, add:
link to VPN instructions

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text:
Project and Storage Locations
After logging in, users usually have access to:

a personal home directory

a project directory linked to the SUPR project

a scratch or temporary directory for short-term work

[MORE INFO NEEDED: Exact directory paths and structure on Gorilla, Pelle, and Lutra]
Please also clarify:

recommended locations for active project data

scratch data retention rules

procedures for long-term storage

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text:
Software and Modules
The systems typically use a module-based environment for software management. Users can list, load, and switch between available tools.
[MORE INFO NEEDED: Confirm the module system in use and list recommended default modules or environments]
If container solutions such as Conda, Apptainer, or Singularity are recommended, link or describe them here.

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text:
Running Jobs
Compute jobs are generally submitted through a batch scheduling system such as SLURM.
[MORE INFO NEEDED: Confirm scheduler type and provide guidance on job submission, job limits, and example workflows]
Clarify:

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
text:
Monitoring Usage and Quotas
Users should monitor:

storage consumption

used and remaining CPU/GPU hours

allocation status

Monitoring may be available via the SUPR web portal or local system tools.
[MORE INFO NEEDED: Describe where users can check quotas and usage metrics]

title: Step 3 – Access and Use of Granted Resources
section: End of Allocation and Data Management
text:
End of Allocation and Data Management
Before the allocation ends, users should:

remove unnecessary intermediate files

transfer long-term data to approved archival storage

ensure compliance with SLU data management and security guidelines

The termination and renewal procedures (notice period, where to request changes, etc.) remain [MORE INFO NEEDED] and will be updated when confirmed.
